DOC.detailed_description: Microincision vitrectomy surgery ( MIVS ) largely replace use conventional , 20-gauge vitrectomy , offer rapid visual recovery , decrease postoperative pain inflammation , reduce surgical time use small diameter instruments1 . Most recently , 27 gauge vitrectomy instrumentation introduced2 , offer additional small gauge option currently available 23 , 25 , 25+ gauge system . Initial experience small gauge MIVS yield mixed result , early report note increase rate wound-related postoperative complication include hypotony , choroidal detachment , endophthalmitis , sclerotomy-related retinal tears3,4 . However , experience instrument modification , outcome MIVS improved1,3 . In 2010 Ophthalmic Technology Assessment report American Academy Ophthalmology , outcomes MIVS find comparable 20 gauge vitrectomy benchmarks5 . Prior study establish two-stage , angle incision result improve wound integrity 23 , 25 , 25+ MIVS systems6,7 , help prevent complication post-operative endophthalmitis hypotony . However , two clinical series describe outcome 27 gauge MIVS , one-stage , perpendicular wound construction perform without complication series 31 patients2,8 . Thus far , direct comparison wound construction technique ( one-stage , perpendicular two-stage , angle ) evaluate . The purpose study prospectively compare clinical outcome use straight , one-stage ( perpendicular ) versus angle , two-stage trocar insertion 27 gauge minimally invasive vitrectomy surgery ( MIVS ) . The design study randomize , clinical trial . Primary outcome sclerotomy suture rate incidence suture blebs end 27 gauge MIVS surgery epiretinal membrane macular pucker indication ( air gas tamponade ) .
